item.title: Camille H add a quote by Jane Bowles
item.description: "True enough,” said Mrs. Copperfield, bringing her fist down on the table and looking very mean. “I have gone to pieces, which is a thing I’ve wanted to do for years. I know I am as guilty as I can be, but I have my happiness, which I guard like a wolf, and I have authority now and a certain amount of daring, which, if you remember correctly, I never had before." -- Jane Bowles

item.title: Camille H add a quote by Charles Portis
item.description: "Listen, here's what I'd like to do: I'd like to live in a trailer and play records all night." -- Charles Portis

item.title: Camille H add a quote by John Kennedy Toole
item.description: "I am at the moment writing a lengthy indictment against our century. When my brain begins to reel from my literary labors, I make an occasional cheese dip." -- John Kennedy Toole

item.title: Camille H add a quote by Sheila Heti
item.description: "He’s just another man who wants to teach me something." -- Sheila Heti

item.title: Camille H add a quote by Flannery O'Connor
item.description: "Total non-retention has kept my education from being a burden to me." -- Flannery O'Connor

item.title: Camille H add a quote by Eugene Walter
item.description: "Summer in the deep South is not only a season, a climate, it's a dimension. Floating in it, one must be either proud or submerged." -- Eugene Walter

item.title: Camille H add a quote by John Edward Williams
item.description: "To read without joy is stupid." -- John Edward Williams

item.title: Camille H add a quote by John Edward Williams
item.description: "Sometimes, immersed in his books, there would come to him the awareness of all that he did not know, of all that he had not read; and the serenity for which he labored was shattered as he realized the little time he had in life to read so much, to learn what he had to know." -- John Edward Williams

item.title: Camille H add a quote by Lafcadio Hearn
item.description: "Times are not good here. The city is crumbling into ashes. It has been buried under taxes and frauds and maladministrations so that it has become a study for archaeologists...but it is better to live here in sackcloth and ashes than to own the whole state of Ohio." -- Lafcadio Hearn
